title: jamie oliver hails ban energy
story: NewsJamie Oliver hails ban on energy drinks as government brings in plans to cut childhood obesityHealth Secretary Jeremy Hunt included the ban in a raft of new proposals including a 9pm watershed on junk food adverts&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud20:51, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJamie Oliver thanked Mirror readers for getting behind the Can It! campaign after a plan to ban the sale of energy drinks to kids was announced. Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt included the ban in a raft of new proposals to cut childhood obesity, including a 9pm watershed on junk food adverts. Jamie, 42, who has campaigned alongside us for a ban, said: “I really think this was driven by the strong support of the Mirror and its readers. These drinks are not fit for kids and are affecting not only them negatively but also classrooms around the country. This is a great move for better child health but also a great move to support our teachers to help kids learn. We need to keep supporting this in the consultation.”  The ban on selling caffeine and sugar-laden drinks, such as Red Bull, to under-16s is included in Mr Hunt’s draft policy which aims to halve childhood obesity by 2030. Mr Hunt was appalled at figures showing energy drinks were being consumed by 25% of six to nine-year-olds. His proposals will be subject to consultation before a final decision. Mr Hunt said: “It is near impossible to shield children from exposure to unhealthy foods. Parents are asking for help. It’s our job to give them power to make healthier choices. The cost of obesity – on individual lives and our NHS – is too great to ignore.”

title: labour vows bring huge defence
story: NewsLabour vows to bring huge defence contracts back under state control in major new policyShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan to scrap deals with outsourcing giants - as she insisted Trident would be kept&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor00:01, 25 JUN 2018Updated00:03, 25 JUN 2018NewsShadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBumper Ministry of Defence contracts will be brought back in-house by a Labour government, military experts will be told today. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith will reveal the party’s plan to scrap deals with outsourcing giants in a bid to raise standards. The frontbencher will point to a series of disasters involving multimillion-pound contracts between MoD the private sector after the Tories hived off deals as they tried to save cash. Ms Griffith, who has held her post since October 2016, has said Labour would back sending more troops to Afghanistan to continue the fight against the Taliban. She told the BBC’s Andrew Marr the party would not not reverse its decision to keep Britain’s Trident nuclear deterrent despite Jeremy Corbyn’s well-publicised opposition to the programme.  The Welsh MP stressed it was party policy to support the nuclear deterrent, saying this was not the time to be “descaling” it. She said: “I think if you look at the world today it’s a more uncertain place than it’s ever been. I think if you look at the way the United States is not stepping up to the mark, I don’t think this is the right time to be getting rid of our nuclear deterrent. Vowing an immediate review of existing contracts and a ban on awarding new deals, Ms Griffith will tell the Royal United Services Institute think tank today: “The next Labour government will get to grips with outsourcing at the MoD. “Upon taking office, we will carry out a root and branch review of significant service contracts that have been outsourced by the Department. “And where they are not delivering, where they are failing our personnel and their families, or failing to provide value for money to British taxpayers, we will have no hesitation in bringing these contracts back in-house.  “And we will call an immediate halt to the significant contracts that are currently being considered for outsourcing, with Labour introducing a clear presumption in favour of public contracts being delivered by the public sector.” The pledge comes after the Government’s decision to hand a contract for the Defence Fire and Rescue Service to Capita, despite the company achieving the highest possible risk rating in an internal MoD assessment. The firm was recently stripped of its contract to run MoD military estates, while its deal to run for recruitment to the Army has been plagued by problems, leaving the Service 5,000 troops below strength. Meanwhile, Service families have repeatedly complained of broken boilers, rattling windows and mouldy walls in homes where a private firm is responsible for upkeep.

title: turkey elections 2018 results erdogan
story: NewsTurkey election: President Erdogan vows to liberate Syria as he tightens grip on power with historic winThe 64-year-old leader overcame the biggest challenge to his rule in more than a decade as he won an absolute majority&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNatalie EvansDave Burke05:03, 25 JUN 2018Updated05:57, 25 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRecep Tayyip Erdogan won Turkey's presidential election on Sunday, overcoming the biggest challenge to his rule in more than a decade. The incumbent leader won an absolute majority with 97.2 percent of the votes counted, Turkey's High Electoral Board (YSK) confirmed. Unofficial results broadcast on Turkish television also gave his ruling party and its alliance partner a majority in parliament. Spokesman Sadi Guven added that the pro-Kurdish People's Democratic Party (HDP) had passed the 10 percent threshold needed to enter parliament. The main opposition party did not immediately concede defeat. But after initially saying Erdogan would fall well short of a first-round victory, it said simply it would continue its democratic struggle whatever the result.  Erdogan addressed supporters in a victory speech from the balcony of his ruling AK Party's headquarters in Ankara. Starting tomorrow, we will start working to realise the promises we made our people, Erdogan told flag-waving supporters. He also pledged that authorities, who have waged a nationwide crackdown since a failed military coup two years ago, would act more decisively against terrorist organisations.  Erdogan, 64, added that Turkish forces would continue to liberate Syrian lands so that the 3.5 million Syrian refugees in Turkey could return home safely. Sunday's vote ushered in a powerful new executive presidency, putting more power in Erdogan's hands Turks narrowly backed the shake-up in a referendum last year.  Erdogan's victory paves the way for another five-year term. Under the new constitution, he could serve a further term from 2023, taking him to 2028. Critics say extending his powers will further erode democracy in Turkey, which is a NATO member state. An unexpectedly strong showing by the AK Party's alliance partner, the nationalist MHP, could translate into the stable parliamentary majority that Erdogan seeks in order to govern freely. This sets the stage for speeding up reforms, Turkish Deputy Prime Minister Mehmet Simsek tweeted of the results. His main rival, Muharrem Ince of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), had earlier urged election monitors to remain at polling stations to guard against possible fraud.  Yesterday, a crowd of Erdogan's supporters chanted his name as he emerged from a school after voting in Turkey's largest city Istanbul, shaking hands with people amid tight security. Turkey is staging a democratic revolution, he told reporters in the polling station. With the presidential system, Turkey is seriously raising the bar, rising above the level of contemporary civilisations.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:07, 23 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting. 1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland  A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer. Bike need replacing?   If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90). And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear. Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:  Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables  2. The Eden Project, Cornwall   Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.  Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination. Camping out?   Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch. Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail. Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). The simple tunnel design is easy to pitch in approximately 20 minutes. With two separate bedrooms and a living area, it's perfect for families or groups of friends. For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.  3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales  The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm. Why not try..   The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.   4. White Nancy, Cheshire   Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week. Need to drive?  Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first. A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.  If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road. 5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland  There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm. 6. Hampstead Heath, London  The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.   7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight   The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. Accessible by bike (and ferry, if you're not an island resident), it's the ideal place to see during the day before you settle down somewhere to watch the sunset. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.  Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. With added electrically powered pedal assistance, it delivers 40 - 50 miles of range through a rear hub motor with speed sensor. This extra power is enough to guarantee effortless rides, taking the strain out of hills and making moving off from a standstill much easier. If you prefer, this bike is also available in a non electric version and in a range of colours - we love the mint green ! The sunset starts at 9:18pm near Osborne House and 9:17pm in Shanklin Chine.  8. Ness Point, Lowestoft    Ness Point is the UK's most easterly point. This makes it a great place to ride to on National Cycle Route 1. Make yourself comfortable on the Halfords XL Waterproof Picnic Blanket , &pound10 (half price) and watch the waves crash in as the sun goes down. Sunset is 9:16 at the UK's most easterly point.  9. Blackpool Pleasure Beach, Lancashire   With plenty of places to cycle in the area you could have an amazing day out in Blackpool. Start with a ride to the Pleasure Beach, and have some fun with the kids (or without them!) on the roller coasters. When all that's done you can have fish and chips while the sun sets on another day. The sun will go set at around 9:43 in Blackpool.  10. Cotswolds, England  Spread over six counties there's a lot to see in the Cotswolds. Consider taking a ride through the picturesque Castle Combe to take in the amazing houses and the stunning market square. The sun sets on this beautiful village at 9:26pm  Find your way by car - and beat the traffic   If you're driving to somewhere new then why not add a sat nav to your car? The TomTom GO 6200 , &pound270, (was &pound339.99, save &pound69.99) adds real-time traffic information to the navigational benefits of a sat nav (smartphone required for this feature).   11. Giant's Causeway, Northern Ireland

title: derelict chalet transformed luxury holiday
story: NewsDerelict chalet transformed into luxury holiday apartment worth £850,000The once unloved Cornish chalet is now an opulent holiday home complete with a hot tub and heated outdoor shower&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMiles O'LearyPippa Allen-Kinross16:04, 24 JUN 2018NewsImagine having breakfast with this view (Image: Unique Home Stays www.uniquehomestays)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA once derelict chalet on the Cornish coastline is now worth a small fortune after two property moguls transformed it into a stunning holiday home. Husband and wife team Katherine and Adam Wooler fell in love with the location of the abandoned chalet off Whitsand Bay, and rebuilt it from the bottom up after negotiating with Cornwall Council to overturn strict planning laws.  Called Seaglass , it comes complete with a natural spa, including a hot tub and heated outdoor shower with a beautiful view of the sea.   It also boasts posh skylights, bi-fold doors that look out onto the ocean, Cornwall Live reports.   The Wooler's rent it and last year alone raked in &pound123,000 from holiday makers - who have even been known to touch down in a private helicopter. But they've decided the time is now right to sell the freehold of the posh apartment as the family enjoys a new start in New Zealand. It's available to buy right now - but you'll need a cool &pound850,000 in your back pocket.  Katherine said: The chalet had to be a similar size to the previous one bedroom chalet, but it was the size of the plot that really attracted us and the sense of isolation from the other chalets dotted along the cliff. It was initially our intention to live there but with the arrival of our baby, Ella-Rose, we decided to turn it into a holiday let. Having previously converted another chalet on the cliff into a holiday let, we were aware of the potential and growing demand in Whitsand Bay - also locally know as ‘Cornwall’s forgotten corner’. We purchased the property in July 2013 and had our first holiday let booking on New Years Eve 2013. We lived in Dorset during the build and were doing day round trips to Cornwall to oversee the build - with a six-month-old baby.

title: family four traumatised masked gang
story: NewsFamily-of-four traumatised as masked gang attack their home with baseball batsAt least eight men in balaclavas smashed the windows and doors of a family home in Plymouth, Devon, leaving Amy Stevens, her partner and two children cowering in fear for their lives&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByWilliam Telford07:52, 25 JUN 2018NewsAmy Stevens with Lee Jeffrey, whose quick-thinking stopped the gang from entering the flat (Image: Plymouth Herald WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family were left in fear for their lives when a gang of masked men attacked their home with baseball bats. Mum-of-two Amy Stevens said they thought they were going to die and her children were petrified following the horrendous incident.  Amy and partner Lee Jeffrey have no idea why around eight balaclava-clad men should target their  property in Whitleigh, Plymouth, which left children Shanella, aged 11, and Amelia, aged seven, traumatised.   It is believed there was also damage caused to the home of a 96-year-old neighbour during the incident, Plymouth Live reports.   The couple now have a repair bill of more than &pound1,000 but say that pales when they think of what could have happened to their children. Shanella had not long left the bathroom when the window was smashed, showering the room with glass. And if Lee, 33, had not locked the front door of the couple’s flat when he saw the men approaching, the couple fear they could have come inside and caused mayhem. “You can fix a window, but if Lee had not been able to lock the front door in time and my daughter had still been in the bathroom I dread to think what would have happened,” said 31-year-old Amy.  “It was awful, the children are shaking every time there is a knock at the door now, but, to be honest, I am too.” Police are investigating the incident but have yet to identify the men involved or the vehicle they escaped in. They are also trying to work out the motive for the attack. The incident happened in the same street where police are still investigating the cause of a blaze which damaged two cars on June 1. Arson has hot been ruled out.  Amy and Lee have no connection to that incident and are mystified as to why anyone should want to attack their property or the family. The drama unfolded at about 11pm on June 23, when Lee was watching TV in the front room of the ground-floor, two-bedroom flat. “He was on the sofa and heard a massive banging and shouting outside,” said Amy. “He looked out and saw about eight men in balaclavas and rushed to lock the front door.  “Then the men started batting hell out of the windows. The smashed all of them.” She said the front door window, another window and all the panes in the bathroom window were smashed. “It was like something you would see on Crimewatch. “They have caused about &pound1,000 of damage.” Police reacted quickly to the incident as soon as the family rang in.

title: gatwick airport flights left without
story: NewsEasyJet planes at Gatwick Airport left without clean water after 'contaminated supply pumped on board'EasyJet passengers have told how they are unable to wash their hands with the plane's water supply after using the toilet, and tea and coffee aren't being served on board&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByChris kitching08:09, 25 JUN 2018Updated10:42, 25 JUN 2018NewsAn easyJet flight attendant carries bottles of water onto a plane at Gatwick Airport (Image: tomharwood83/Twitter)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEasyJet flights out of Gatwick Airport have been left without clean water after the supply to planes was contaminated, say angry passengers. Travellers say they are unable to wash their hands with the plane's water supply after using the toilet. Tea and coffee aren't being served during flights, and passengers have been told to bring their own bottled water on board. Passengers told how their flights were delayed for up to two hours because the water supply was contaminated and the crew were waiting for a delivery of bottled water. One passenger said a pilot announced every plane on the tarmac was affected.  Actress Rebecca Mansfield told : There was an issue with the water that’s been uploaded to all the planes on the tarmac, so they all had to receive bottled water before take off. We’ve been delayed by over an hour waiting for one solitary crate of Harrogate water bottles to arrive. No tea or coffee on board, and no running water in the bathroom but they’re providing hand sanitiser.   We don’t know what the issue with the water is but it hasn’t affected the airport - it’s only the water that has been uploaded onto the aircraft, apparently. Ms Mansfield, who was flying to the Greek island of Santorini, added: We were told by the pilot that it wasn’t just us and that every aircraft on the tarmac was in the same situation. Earlier, she had written on Twitter: Sitting on the tarmac at @Gatwick_Airport because the water on board is contaminated or some b******s.

title: mum in pieces man who
story: NewsMum 'in pieces' as man who killed her daughter is allowed day release for his dad's funeralAlmost nine years to the day since bouncer Phillip Steven Packer strangled his ex-girlfriend Jenna Thomas, of North Cornelly, Wales, he is being given day release from prison&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJessica Walford08:29, 25 JUN 2018NewsPhillip Steven Packer refused to accept his relationship with Jenna had broken down (Image: Wales Online WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum whose daughter was murdered by her ex-boyfriend said she is in pieces about a decision to grant him day release to go to his father's funeral - nearly nine years to the day since she was killed. In June 2009, Jenna Thomas was strangled by nightclub bouncer Phillip Steven Packer after he refused to accept their relationship had broken down.  Now, the killer is being given day release on June 29 and Jenna's mum Kay Thomas, from North Cornelly near Bridgend, is furious, Wales Online reports.  She says she was only informed of the decision a week before by her victim liaison officer - and now fears she won't be able to stop it going ahead.  As far as I'm concerned he should have lost his rights when he strangled my daughter, the 60-year-old said. A lot of my family's ashes are buried there [at the crematorium]. Can you imagine how angry I am? It's nine years on Sunday that he strangled her. I don't think he should have the right to come out. I've got no rights at all. I'm in pieces. How would any mother feel? Because he couldn't have her, nobody could have her. Kay has now appealed the decision. Jenna and Phillip had met at Apollo nightclub in Porthcawl, Bridgend, where Miss Thomas worked as a barmaid, and Packer as a doorman.  Packer’s marriage broke up and the couple moved into a flat on the Esplanade in the Welsh town, but their relationship deteriorated as Packer became more controlling. In May 2009 Miss Thomas moved back into her family home in North Cornelly, but Packer struggled to come to terms with the end of the relationship and bombarded her with text messages and telephone calls. Miss Thomas then met a new man, Ian Walters, who was the same age as her, and Packer soon confronted her about seeing him. On June 24, he offered to drive Miss Thomas to work, took her to a cafe for some breakfast and then drove her to a Stormy Down lay-by, where he killed her. He then drove her body to the town's police station. Nine years after the terrible incident, Kay is still struggling to come to terms with what happened.

title: mum threes torment after freak
story: NewsMum-of-three's torment after freak fall eight years ago leads to right leg amputationJulie Banwell, from Huddersfield, West Yorks., has endured crippling pain, taken up to 50 tablets every day and had physiotherapy since 2010&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly21:23, 24 JUN 2018Updated22:47, 24 JUN 2018NewsThe mum has had to have her right led amputated (Image: MEN Media)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum has spoken of her grief at having to have her right leg amputated — as a result of a freak fall off concrete steps eight YEARS ago.  Julie Banwell, 43, has spent the best part of a decade suffering debilitating pain, undergoing operations and taking up to 50 tablets a day. And the mother-of-three recently had her limb amputated, a move deemed by doctors the only option to end her crippling agony. Julie, of Newsome, near Huddersfield in West Yorks., stumbled on concrete steps as she took her then five-year-old son to school back in April 2010.  She had stitches in her knee but was diagnosed with the rare complex regional pain syndrome 18 months later. Julie, who works in education, said: I was an active mother and after a simple fall taking my little boy to school I haven’t been able to walk. There is no cure, just lots of treatments that do not help.  “I have been to every hospital across Yorkshire and had three knee operations, phyisotherapy, lidocaine infusions, acupuncture, steroid injections into the leg and even a spinal cord stimulator implant.  “I’ve had loads of blood clots and was having to take 50 tablets a day. I have had every painkiller you can think of.” But late last year, specialists at Huddersfield Royal Infirmary decided she must have the leg amputated.  Medics gave Julie only a 50/50 chance of the operation working but the surgery, carried out last week, appears to have been successful. I feel fantastic and I can’t thank everybody at the hospital enough for what they have done for me — they have been wonderful, Julie added. She is hoping the next step will be to have a prosthetic limb fitted. However, that too is beset with complications with Julie saying there is only a 50-50 chance of it happening. The mum continued: She added: “I’m very determined and would love to be able to walk again. I am just hoping that I can walk and have a life like other people.”

title: sickening clip emerges teenage boys
story: News'Sickening' clip emerges of teenage boys abusing cancer-survivor gran — and they then share it on SnapchatDisgusted social media users demanded the youths 'have their mouths washed out' and they 'learn some respect' after the clip was shared widely online&nbspShareByIan JohnsonBradley Jolly21:22, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email This is the sickening moment a gran was abused by teenage yobs at a bus stop.  The vile youths swear at the cancer-survivor and compare her to a dog in the shocking clip.  The victim has been left traumatised after the abuse, in the clip Chronicle Live says was quickly shared on Snapchat .  It's now been viewed more than 300,000 times by disgusted social media users who have condemned the boys. Police are investigating the incident, believed to have happened in Hebburn, Tyne and Wear.  The pensioner, who does not want to be named, said: I hadn’t done anything wrong to them and they treat me like that - I felt a bit sick. Kids today are terrible - they have no respect for people. I'd hate to think my children would go on like that but I know they wouldn’t. “You just can’t go around treating people like that. The grandma had left her home for just the second time in 10 months, having been in hospital.   Some Facebook users called for her abusers to have “their mouths washed out”. Another said they should undertake “mandatory national service” to learn respect.  “If they were my children, I’d drag them around to the victim’s house to apologise and make them work in the garden for six months,” said the victim's furious son. He added: She’s a lovely, quiet lady so where do kids get off these days by doing this?. “I was telling my partner today, once upon a time if a ball went into someone’s garden you would politely ask for it back. “But kids are going around swearing and doing this with no respect — they are a nightmare. “She was so proud to go back on the bus for the first time — she rang me and said ‘guess where I am’. “She was so pleased with herself, then she went out yesterday and this happened.”  “We will not let her out now because of this — she could have fallen over to get away and fractured her hip, and you don’t know what the consequences could have been. “But you just think of these kids, ‘how were you brought up?’.” Robin Armstrong, an actor and comedian from Tyne and Wear, was appalled to watch the 45-second clip and shared it with his fans. He said: “Abusing a nana is the ultimate no _ they are the heart of a family. “To hear her being called a dog and on the phone to her family, she’s worried — it is just sickening. “I was in total disbelief — I couldn’t believe the kids would do it. “I wish I was there to have sorted it. “As soon as I got the clip, I wanted to get it up there and find out who they are.”

title: uk weather britain hotter sahara
story: NewsUK weather: Brits hit the beach for weekend heatwave ahead of 'hotter than Sahara' 33C sizzlerA ‘Spanish blowtorch’ heatwave will send the mercury soaring to 33C in what forecaster are predicting could be the first of up to EIGHT heatwaves this summer&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHenry Vaughan06:48, 25 JUN 2018Updated07:18, 25 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain will be hotter than the Sahara desert this week as the country sizzles in the first of up to EIGHT heatwaves predicted this summer. A 10-day ‘Spanish blowtorch’ heatwave will send the mercury soaring to 33C from Wednesday - making it potentially the hottest day of the year so far. Temperatures will begin to rise from Tuesday after an already baking weekend saw millions flock to beaches and beer gardens up and down the country. Scores of people were out enjoying the sunshine as they watched England beat Panama 6-1 in the World Cup - and it looks like it'll be hotting up even further as England makes its way to the knock-out stages.  After a “marvellous” Midsummer’s Day at 27C, the Met Office forecast 30C by Tuesday and up to 33C on Wednesday and Thursday. Up to eight summer roasts are now predicted ahead – with each spell reaching at least 28C, according to AccuWeather, the world’s second biggest commercial forecaster. Britain will be matching Nouakchott, Mauritania on the edge of the Sahara Desert, by the middle of the week, where temperaturesare set to be around 31C on Wednesday. The hottest day so far this year came in April when a temperature of 29.1C was recorded in London.  Met Office forecaster Sophie Yeomans said: We would expect at some point this week to beat that. We are going to continue with the dry and sunny weather for most places. Top temperatures are going to be on the rise. We could see temperatures into the low 30s some time this week, possibly from Tuesday, but more likely from Wednesday. The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “A blowtorch feed of hot air will come from Spain.”

title: american woman flies 4000 miles
story: NewsAmerican woman flies 4,000 miles to UK to tell pal "you're it" in epic game of international tagGeorgina Wilkinson tagged friend Drew McEwan shortly after landing, ran away and caught an eight-hour flight home&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJackie Grant07:10, 25 JUN 2018Updated10:43, 25 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn American woman flew 4,000 miles to the UK to tell her pal you're it in an epic game of international tag - and then immediately jetted home. Drew McEwan was left stunned when Georgina Wilkinson, disguised as a gardener, showed up at his niece's christening. Georgina posed as a gardener as Drew and his family were taking photos at Loch Lomond in southern Scotland. After flying in that morning, she tagged him and ran away laughing - and then hopped on an eight-hour flight home that afternoon, the Daily Record reports.  Drew, Georgina and eight others have been playing the bizarre game since they all met by chance in China in 2014. Georgina had arranged to get one over on Drew with the help of his brother and sister and kept it under wraps until last Friday. And while the family photos were being taken after the christening, the photographer, who was also in on the joke, asked Drew if he could tell the gardener working away in the background to move because he was in the shot.  But Drew was left stunned when 'gardener' Georgina stood up, tagged him and then ran away. Digital consultant Drew, 31, tsaid: “My brother and sister had been planning it for months with Georgina behind my back. They even picked her up at the airport that morning. “I’ve never felt so betrayed by my own flesh and blood.”  Drew, originally from Newton Stewart in Dumfries and Galloway, added: “I didn’t even get a chance to talk to Georgina. You have to just tag and run, you can’t stay and chat. “I was in shock that she’d put so much effort into it. Flying over from America and back in one day is unbelievable. She had to make sure she was home in plenty of time for work on Monday. It’s my turn to tag one of the group now. “Obviously I’m not pleased with the bar Georgina’s raised for me but I must admit it was brilliantly executed.  “It was captured on video and you can see how surprised I was when I realised the gardener was actually Georgina. “When the video was posted on Facebook, it was unbelievable how many comments and messages we received. “To top Georgina’s tag, my one will need to be captured on video, I’ll need to have a great costume and it will need to involve international travel. I’m not telling a soul what I’m planning though. I’ll need to keep it as much as a surprise as Georgina did with me.”  Drew’s sister Angela enjoyed helping Georgina with the elaborate hoax. “It was the most fun to plan and I’m so glad we got to be part of this infamous game of international tag”, she said. Georgina thanked the Angela for “allowing me to ruin a cherished family occasion. In particular Angela for offering up her daughter’s baptism in the name of fun. She added: “Sorry Drewbs, you are now... it.”

title: boy caught camera licking chicken
story: NewsBoy caught on camera licking chicken advert on billboard as he waits outside restaurantHarvey Quesa thought the food was real and even tried to grab a piece&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly22:15, 24 JUN 2018Updated22:25, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A hungry little boy tried to eat the food pictured on a fried chicken advert .   Harvey Quesa's amused family filmed the youngster stare longingly at the poster and start attempting to eat imaginary pieces of the chicken .   The clip, which was filmed in Bayambang in the Philippines, has been viewed more than 11 million times on Facebook since it was shared earlier this month.   The three-year-old's family had decided to enjoy breakfast at Jollibee, a popular fast food chain in the country.    The restaurant though was closed when they arrived.  The cute youngster's aunty, Va Nes Sa, said: We decided to just wait in front of the restaurant until it opened. While my cousin and I were waiting outside, we just let Harvey walk around because there wasn’t many people around at that time in the morning. It was only recently that Harvey had became obsessed with fried chicken because he could only eat soft foods before that.  Harvey was just so eager to go inside to eat the chicken that he tried to push the restaurant door open, telling the staff 'Hey guys, open!'. Harvey with his imagination decided to sit down in front of Jollibee’s advertising poster and eat the fried chicken in the advert instead.

title: english bulldog called zsa zsa
story: NewsEnglish bulldog called Zsa Zsa with 'shower of slobber' named the World's Ugliest DogThe nine-year-old canine narrowly beat 'Zombie Dog' Charlie to win her owner $1,500 (£1,130) in California&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly23:00, 24 JUN 2018Updated23:01, 24 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An English bulldog with a shower of slobber, droopy tongue and painted nails was crowned the World's Ugliest Dog at an official contest on Saturday.  Zsa Zsa, a stout and barrel-chested nine-year-old dog, beat 13 other canines to the title and won her proud owner $1,500 (&pound1,130) and a trophy. Celebrity judges in Petaluma, near San Francisco in California, were impressed with the mutt's wrinkled face, protruded teeth and shower of slubber. It was a very difficult decision. We loved all of the dogs, said reporter and judge Jo Ling Kent.  It was a huge responsibility, and we are just so happy for Zsa Zsa. The wacky contest, which this year was its 30th, said in a statement: Nine years young with a swaggering tongue, Zsa Zsa delivered a shower of slobber as she claimed this year's title. But she faced fierce competition from Charlie, dubbed Zombie Dog, for his sparse hair and spooky look.  Rascal Deux was vying to win the gong for the seventh time but his crazy eyes and hairless look wasn't enough. A beefy exercise intolerant bulldog named Meatloaf (aka Snorlax) and a terrier with dreadlocks also wowed the panel. Zsa Zsa, like most of the contenders, has had a tough life. She was rescued from a puppy farm, where she was bred for five years. She now lives with owner Megan Brainard in Minnesota.  The organisers say the contest isn't to mock the pets. Instead, they stress the idea is to celebrate the diversity of dogs across the world.

title: mount everest climber who survived
story: NewsMount Everest climber who survived disaster that killed eight on peak died after falling down steps at homeCharlotte Fox spent her life travelling the world and scaling the world’s most beautiful, and dangerous, peaks&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByOliver Milne21:09, 24 JUN 2018NewsCharlotte Fox had spoken of doing one more climb in Nepal&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Charlotte Fox spent her 39th birthday on top of the world as she fulfilled her dream of climbing Mount Everest .  But hours after reaching the summit, the passionate mountaineer would find herself huddled in the foetal position, praying “death would come quickly”. She feared she would lose her life on the peak like so many others before her. Charlotte was made of sterner stuff than she thought, however, and after two days battling unimaginable conditions, she made it down the mountain. It was just one extraordinary day for a woman who spent her life travelling the world and scaling the world’s most beautiful, and dangerous, peaks. Tragically, she died last month after falling down steps outside her home, at the age of 61. By the time she took on the challenge of the world’s tallest mountain, Charlotte had already scaled all 53 of the 14,000ft peaks in western US state Colorado.  Her amazing survival story was immortalised in 2015 film Everest, starring Jake Gyllenhaal as Scott Fischer, a mountain guide, Keira Knightley, plus Amy Shindler as Charlotte. It was on May 10, 1996, now infamous in the mountaineering world, that Charlotte and 11 other climbers who had scaled the 29,029ft mountain were caught in a blizzard as they began their descent. The party were well aware that on Everest, rapidly changing weather isn’t just an inconvenience, it can be a death sentence. They found themselves caught in a whiteout, meaning it was impossible to tell which way they were going. Despite having rapidly depleting supplies of oxygen, used to help them breathe in the thin mountain air, the group had no option but to stop. The freezing winds caused Charlotte’s contact lenses to freeze on to her eyes. It was then, as the temperatures dropped to -50C and the winds roared at 70mph, that Charlotte curled up and waited for the end.  For two days the mountaineers battled to survive as snow battered them on the Southeast Ridge. Charlotte later recalled: “We waited for that warm fuzzy feeling that accompanied hypothermia and death.”  The storm eventually cleared, but eight of the men and women who had journeyed up the mountain would never come down again, including Fischer. It remains one of the worst disasters to happen on Everest. More than 375 people have died trying to climb it.  Writing in the American Alpine Journal, Charlotte described the relief that followed the storm’s passing. “Miraculously, the storm abated. Half-frozen we staggered to our feet and made an attempt to shuffle off. “My knees kept buckling and I couldn’t seem to make headway.” Just yards from the relative safety of her tent, Charlotte collapsed. It was Russian climber Anatoli Boukreev, who returned with an oxygen tank and dragged her back to camp, who saved her life. Later, people blamed the tragedy on the commercialisation of Everest. But for Charlotte, it was a dark episode during a life dedicated to mountaineering. During the summer before her ordeal she had tackled two other climbs in the Himalayas exceeding 26,300ft, Gasherbrum II and Cho Oyu. An only child born in North Carolina, Charlotte was a self-described “Southern belle” with a lifelong love of the outdoors and adventure. After graduating from university, she fell in love with the Rocky Mountains and made the state of Colorado her home. There, she became a talented waterskier and found a job in mountain rescue, living among the peaks that were her passion. She described herself as an “eternal fun hog”. Yet her disastrous descent from Everest was not the only time tragedy would strike in her life. In 1993 her boyfriend Mark Bebie was climbing in the Canadian Rockies when he died in an avalanche.  Heartbreak would strike again in 2004 when her husband of four years, Reese Martin III, died in a paragliding accident. But the loss of two loved ones did not leave Charlotte bitter. “I was never mad at Mark or Reese for dying in their pursuit of living,” she said. And despite multiple tragedies on the mountainside, Charlotte refused to give up her thrill-seeking. In the 22 years of her life which followed Everest, she scaled countless others but never returned to the mountain that almost took her life. But when asked to reflect on the tragedy which defined so much of her life, she said: “A bunch of people went climbing, each with his or her own reasons. There were no heroes or villains.” Her friends were distraught when on May 24 she was found dead at her home in Telluride, Colorado. She had celebrated her birthday just two weeks earlier. Charlotte died after falling down 77 hardwood steps outside her four-floor house. It had a lift but, despite sometimes being injured from her many climbs, she refused to use it as she wanted to stay fit on the stairs.

title: mum pinned down shredded black
story: NewsMum 'shredded' by hungry bear survives after desperate husband punched creature while it gnawed her legsWARNING - GRAPHIC CONTENT: Mum-of-three Casadi Schroeder, 33, had a miracle escape after being pinned to a Canadian forest floor in an attack that left her needing 34 staples in her leg&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByPatricia Murphy10:16, 25 JUN 2018Updated10:38, 25 JUN 2018NewsCasadi Schroeder is lucky to be alive after her run in with a black bear (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has told of her remarkable escape after being pinned down and mauled by a black bear in a dawn attack at a gospel camp. Casadi Schroeder, 33, needed 34 staples in her leg after the frightening attack in which an American black bear pinned her down on the forest floor. The mother-of-three was guest speaking at a Bethel Gospel Camp when she awoke to the bear attempting to claw through her cabin door on June 10. Casadi and her pastor husband Brad Schroeder, 33, scared the bear away but they feared the animal would attack a group of children sleeping in a tent near the food hall.  The couple did not have a phone signal while camping in Jeanette Lake in Meadow Lake Provincial Park, Saskatchewan, and were unable to raise the alarm. Keeping a safe distance from the bear, Casadi followed the animal to the food hall to warn campers and disturbed him attempting to climb into the building’s window. The stay-at-home mum, of Lanigan, Saskatchewan, Canada, said she didn’t fear the bear until it began to charge at her, pinning her down and digging its teeth into her leg. Watching his wife from the cabin window, Brad ran to her aid and began kicking and punching the bear as it gnawed on her legs. Casadi said: “There was no cell service and I felt really anxious. “I knew there were kids sleeping in a pop-up tent on the way to the camp’s kitchen and I thought if he was hungry they weren’t safe. “I told my husband that I didn’t feel good about it.  “I was keeping a good distance from the bear but I knew I had to warn people. There was no cell service at this camp so I couldn’t call anyone. “When I took the blind corner at the kitchen, I saw the bear looking in the window. “When he saw me, he stopped and turned around. “I wasn’t scared at that point I just thought he was curious and I knew bear attacks were uncommon. “In what felt like the blink of an eye he was right in front of me charging toward me and I started to panic. “I knew I needed to stay calm and not run, but back away slowly. “He started running at me really fast.  I felt his teeth sink into my leg. I was so shocked I began yelling at the top of my lungs. “He was biting me so deep, it felt like it was to the bone. “I thought I was going to die. I spoke to Jesus at that moment and said, ‘I am ready to go’. “I knew that if he went anywhere near my neck I was going to be dead. “The next thing I saw was this barefoot kick the bear right into his head. It was my husband.” Brad added: “In a situation like that you don’t even have time to think you just run. “I have little snippets of memory but all I wanted to do was get that bear off her.”  The bear released Casadi and she managed to run to the nearest cabin where its occupants pulled her inside to safety and alerted 911. In the meantime, Brad ran to their cabin to make sure the couple’s children Noah, eight, Mika, six, and Phin, two, were safely locked inside. The ambulance arrived at the remote camp an hour later and rushed Casadi to Meadow Lake Hospital where her wounded legs were stitched together with 34 staples. Casadi said: “The doctor told me my injuries were the best-case scenario. “If that bear had bitten me from the waist up I’d probably have life-threatening injuries. “I think it was God and Jesus who ensured that it wasn’t more serious and that the damage wasn’t life-threatening.” Conservation officers later trapped the black bear and put it down, fearing it was suffering from rabies and matching its DNA to a hair found on Casadi’s clothes. A spokesperson from the Ministry of Environment said: “Conservation officers trapped a black bear in the area Sunday afternoon that appeared to be similar to the one involved in the attack. “The bear was put down and sent to the University of Saskatchewan for a necropsy. DNA samples were also sent to the Alberta Fish and Wildlife lab in Edmonton for testing.” Those tests have confirmed that the bear captured and put down was the same bear involved in the attack.

title: russian beast thought extinct 60
story: NewsRussian beast thought extinct for 60 YEARS 'spotted roaming mountains by stunned tourists'The Sailugem bear had not been seen since the middle of the last century - with some experts even suggesting it was a mythical creature&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByWill StewartSophie Evans09:39, 25 JUN 2018NewsThis picture appears to show the Sailugem bear 'alive and thriving' in the Altai Mountains (Image: Kaichi Travel/The Siberian Times)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A rare beast believed extinct for decades has been spotted roaming a mountain range in Russia by stunned tourists.   The Sailugem bear had not been seen since the middle of the last century, with some experts even suggesting it was a mythical creature.  But these remarkable new pictures appear to prove the blond-coloured animal is alive and thriving in the Altai Mountains. It was found in a remote area, close to a point where the frontiers of Russia, Mongolia, China and Kazakhstan meet at an intersection.    Video: Previous cub sighting     Shocked tourists from Kaichi Travel spotted the bear while on a trip aimed at observing rare birds of prey and argali mountain sheep.  It was as if the visitors had seen a “ghost”, a representative said. For some years, scientists believed there was evidence of the white-clawed predator’s existence but not enough to prove in a scientific journal. In 2015, reports said experts had found dens and paw prints suggesting the bear was thriving many decades after it had been all but written off. The following year, images and video showed a cub - but dark in colour. At the time, a mother bear, presumably accompanying its offspring, was not seen by the 'camera trap' in the Saylyugem - or Sailugem - National Park.  However, new pictures from the tourist group - which organises tours for foreigners to far-flung Siberian destinations - appear to show for the first time an adult Sailugem bear closely resembling old artistic impressions of the wild animal.  The images, which were captured this month, resemble an artist's impression of the bear made in the Soviet era, The Siberian Times reports.  The best guess from scientists is that the unstudied beast is a rare subspecies of the brown bear, prolific further north. Russian zoologist Dr Genrikh Sobamsky spotted the bear in the middle of the last century and was later instrumental putting it in the Russian red book amid fears it was in peril. The new sighting resembles his artist's impression of the 'vanished' animal based on sightings in the last century.  “An absolutely incredible event took place in our June trip,” said a Kaichi Travel representative. “We met a wild bear, and not a common brown bear but almost a ghost – the Sailugem bear.” Tour guides from the travel company had ushered the party down a steep slope. The account continued: “When we arrived at a flat rock, we noticed the leg of a big fluffy animal some 60-70 metres below us (197 to 230 ft). “Soon it showed itself completely, and to our surprise, it was a real Sailugem bear, blond and very beautiful. “It walked around a bit and we were happy we could make some pictures… as evidence, just to show the world the Sailugem bear really exists.” The tourist group were “really excited and impressed at that moment” and knew they had seen something very special.

story: NewsTurkey election: Government declares Erdogan victory as president tightens grip on powerErdogan's main presidential rival, Muharrem Ince of the opposition Republican People's Party (CHP), had earlier urged election monitors to remain at polling stations to help ensure against possible fraud&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDave Burke20:52, 24 JUN 2018NewsRecep Tayyip Erdogan's grip on Turkey is set to get tighter after today's result (Image: REX/Shutterstock)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Turkish government has declared victory in todays elections, continuing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's grip on power. However his AK Party had been expected to secure a larger win as voters went to the polls, and opponents have yet to accept the result. As counting went on, his lead over rivals got narrower, but he is believed to have secured the 50% required to avoid a runoff. Erdogan was at 52.8%, with 95.1% of the votes counted, broadcasters said.
